body: @vishalsuvagia Thank you for the reminder. I've changed the indent-width to 2 and committed it. This indeed makes it easier to review. However, there are still a massive 900 files, which I believe makes manual review very difficult. We can only rely on unit tests and subsequent bug reports after usage. Currently, the unit tests have passed, and I've deployed a complete cluster in my environment without finding any issues so far. Theoretically, code formatting tools like ruff shouldn't change the code semantics.

@virajjasani  I have resolved some of the test failures. The number of unit test failures has been reduced from 48 to 28. There are still some that are temporarily difficult to solve, which will be completed later. Can you please help review and merge this into the apache:upgrade/jdk-spring-dependencies branch?
@virajjasani Could you help review this pr?

> @tarihub looks like CI has not run for this PR. Can you rebase and push again? @sandeep318kumar hello, I merge the latest commit, but CI still not run update: CI may seems run, but I don't have jenkins permission to see detail

@virajjasani Could you help review this pr?

@JiaLiangC Can you help review this PR? Thanks.

@sandeep318kumar Could you submit all these upgrades to the upgrade branch and include them in this issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AMBARI-26217?
@sandeep318kumar Could you submit all these upgrades to the upgrade branch and include them in this issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AMBARI-26217?

@vanshuhassija  Thank you very much for your contribution. It is recommended that major changes be developed in a separate feature branch. If the changes can be completed before the release, they can be merged. Otherwise, due to the large scope of the changes and the relatively small number of active contributors in the community, it may impact the release of the next version.

@JiaLiangC The change does not impact the existing functionality in any way except the packaging for ambari-admin. The packaging changes have been tested thoroughly. 
With this change a parallel new implementation of admin view is implemented and in no way and under no circumstances, changes will be required in the current Angular implementation.
https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/2ceb283a-8bb4-44c2-83a4-b6182fa739b6
@zRains WDYT？
Sure. I'll raise.
@JiaLiangC I am not upgrading the snakeyaml here. I am just excluding it to resolve CVEs. Shall I still raise this to upgrade branch?

Great changes! This could be the start of a new stage for web updates. I applied your code and tried running it locally, but I encountered a few issues: 1. There's an unnecessary vite.config.js file, and the static asset entry isn't correctly configured in vite.config.ts. 2. tsconfig.node.json file no found. 3. The Bootstrap styles aren't compatible with the current Sass loader, leading to numerous warnings in the console. 4. Some React-related errors appear after launching. 6. There are missing test cases and service request logic. IMO, these issues might take considerable time to resolve. Additionally, there are still some problems with the previous jQuery upgrade. - [x] #3770 Therefore, I think it would be better to develop this upgrade on a new branch. Thanks for all your hard work, and I hope we can complete this change together:P
@JiaLiangC Can you take a look when you have time? thanks.
@JiaLiangC  Can you take a look when you have time? thanks

I have merged these changes into another PR: #3872 
So, closed this PR, thanks.

@vanshuhassija I believe this approach isn't ideal. The issues from the jQuery upgrade are still being addressed, and merging WIP code and files again will complicate troubleshooting. While I understand there are some isolation measures, this fundamentally undermines the long-term integrity of the main branch. It's suited for minor enhancements and fixes, but modular changes like these are precisely what a separate branch should handle.

Regarding contributions, I think prioritizing the creation of a roadmap and sharing it with the community is a better choice. Submitting WIP code to main branch feels irresponsible.
@zRains makes sense. Will raise the progress in a new branch. While there exist the tickets for the required features mapped to the parent feature, a detailed roadmap will be shared as well.

@sandeep318kumar Since the previous /jdk-spring-dependencies was not correct, I updated it and submitted a PR for verification. All tests have passed. Your PR's CI/CD failed. You can take a look at the PR I submitted based on upgrade/jdk-spring-dependencies. The CI/CD has passed: https://github.com/apache/ambari/pull/3873"

Let me know if you need further adjustments!
@vanshuhassija  Hello, I have created a branch for the Ambari frontend refactoring called `frontend-refactor`. Could you please submit the PR to this branch?
Sure @JiaLiangC . Will do that
Closing this PR. A new one #3874 is raised for `frontend-refactor` branch

hi bro I need your help with installing Ambari server can you please share me doc for this step-by-step

> hi bro I need your help with installing Ambari server can you please share me doc for this step-by-step

I don't have a ready-made document. 

The README document does not provide detailed instructions on how to build and install the project.
Perhaps we need to add a new document in the repository.
Introduce that how to build this project and how to install it.
i tried so many times to build and install but Ambari server is not started getting error key error

> i tried so many times to build and install but Ambari server is not started getting error key error

I build ambari by the follow cmd on centos7, for your reference.  @chowreddyG 
```shell
mvn clean install rpm:rpm -DskipTests -Drat.skip=true -DbuildNumber=5895e4ed6b30a2da8a90fee2403b6cab91d19972
```
i need to install ambari server in ubuntu22 version

The official Ambari currently does not support Ubuntu 22 for the time being. However, support is planned for the future. If you have some coding skills, you can modify the Bigtop code and use Bigtop + Ambari to enable support.
okay thanks for updating which version support for ubuntu I need to install and use ambari server

@arshadmohammad May I ask what the build command was when you released version 2.7.8? I am trying to compile version 2.7.8, but I am encountering many errors. Here is the build command I am using:
mvn -B clean install package -Drat.skip=true -DskipTests -Dmaven.test.skip=true -Dfindbugs.skip=true

@yaruyng  It is recommended to create an issue for each commit. If you don't have an issue account, you can request community members to help create one.
@arshadmohammad I think we should merge this now. It's anyways going to block new releases right?
@JiaLiangC Can you help review this PR? Thanks.

@brahmareddybattula  @vanshuhassija  thi pr has introduced almost 30 bugs, many of which are critical, causing major functionalities to break and disrupting most of the unit tests. They haven't been fixed yet. Here is the bug list:https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AMBARI-26237. Could you take a look, and help fixing them?

> @arshadmohammad May I ask what the build command was when you released version 2.7.8? I am trying to compile version 2.7.8, but I am encountering many errors. Here is the build command I am using: mvn -B clean install package -Drat.skip=true -DskipTests -Dmaven.test.skip=true -Dfindbugs.skip=true

Used the same commands as mentioned in wiki https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AMBARI/Installation+Guide+for+Ambari+2.7.8. 
The ambari-logsearch and ambari-infra components were failing, but this issue was ignored. Attempts to remove ambari-logsearch and ambari-infra from the default build profile were made; however, consensus could not be reached with the other developers(Reference: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AMBARI-26034)

> @arshadmohammad I think we should merge this now. It's anyways going to block new releases right?

Yes, I agree.
@JiaLiangC would you like to merge this PR for 2.7.9 release.

> @arshadmohammad thanks for working on this. Any chance to give how it's broken..? and looks CI is failing, would want to take a look.?

I'll run the tests locally to verify, and if there are no issues, I'll merge it in.

This is very big PR :)
Do we want to backport to branch-2.7 as well?

> Do we want to backport to branch-2.7 as well?

This won't be backported to 2.7. Due to HDP's closed source, 2.7 is rarely used anymore. Perhaps it's time to consider it end-of-life.

@zRains We are not adding tsconfig files to git.
I have added tsconfig.node.json file and tests passed.


![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/35182d3c-da29-49f7-a1d5-a0b8f974c8be)


content of tsconfig.node.json

{
    "compilerOptions": {
      "target": "ES2022",
      "lib": ["ES2023"],
      "module": "ESNext",
      "skipLibCheck": true,

      /* Bundler mode */
      "moduleResolution": "bundler",
      "allowImportingTsExtensions": true,
      "isolatedModules": true,
      "moduleDetection": "force",
      "noEmit": true,

      /* Linting */
      "strict": true,
      "noUnusedLocals": true,
      "noUnusedParameters": true,
      "noFallthroughCasesInSwitch": true
    },
    "include": ["vite.config.ts"]
}

can you once add this and try?

@sandeep318kumar The Apache foundation team updated the CI environment, which caused incorrect redirect links here. I'll provide you with a link, please check if you can open it. https://ci-hadoop.apache.org/job/Ambari/job/Ambari-PreCommit-GitHub-PR/view/change-requests/job/PR-3871/ 
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/cddb173c-1769-4059-a42b-900878a788cc)
full log: https://ci-hadoop.apache.org/job/Ambari/job/Ambari-PreCommit-GitHub-PR/view/change-requests/job/PR-3871/6/console
Thanks @JiaLiangC I am able to open this.
@sandeep318kumar This is an uncommon practice. Could you explain why you chose to ignore this file?

Correct @zRains, I am not ignoring these files. 
After running `npm i`
these files are being added in .gitignore automatically.

```
*tsconfig.app.tsbuildinfo
*tsconfig.node.json
*tsconfig.node.tsbuildinfo
```

now I have added tsconfig.node.json file separately, test cases should be working fine. 
@zRains can you run the test cases now?

> After running npm i
these files are being added in .gitignore automatically.


@sandeep318kumar I removed these lines from the .gitignore file and ran `npm i` again, but the file wasn’t added automatically. Here’s my development environment:

```text
OS: Ubuntu Jammy 22.04 x86_64
Kernel: Linux 5.15.0-126-generic
Shell: bash 5.1.16
CPU: 4 x AMD Ryzen 7 7840HS w/ Radeon 780M Graphics (4) @ 3.79 GHz
Node: v20.18.1
PackageManager: pnpm@9.15.0
```

IMO, `tsconfig.node.json` shouldn’t be ignored, as this might lead to inconsistencies in each developer's working environment, potentially causing unexpected issues down the line. I checked this part of the code using `git blame` and found that it was committed by @vanshuhassija. Perhaps they have a different perspective?

https://github.com/apache/ambari/commit/66f6803d200423b179b4412638e58f4c47ba0f94#diff-999547fd46d36ec2ad1d5c872332f2abdacc1b0cb06773066470a278ae92686eR26
@zRains seems like that might have been a mistake. Will remove it from gitignore and add the file
